biogHist.abstract: Princess Margaret Hospital for Children (PMH) was established in 1909 in Subiaco as the Perth Children's Hospital. It was common for children who were in out of home 'care' to be sent there for medical treatment, and children with intellectual disabilities or serious medical conditions sometimes lived at the hospital.
biogHist.p: Princess Margaret Hospital for Children (PMH) was established in 1909 as the Perth Children's Hospital Inc on the corner of Thomas and Hay Streets in Subiaco. A children's ward at the Perth Public Hospital had opened in 1900 but the demands of a rapidly growing population led to the need for a dedicated children's hospital.

In 1949, the Perth Children's Hospital was named after Princess Margaret. Many children who were in out of home care were treated in the Perth Children's/Princess Margaret Hospital, and other children with intellectual disabilities or serious medical conditions sometimes lived there.

chronItem.event: Event - The foundation stone for the Children's Hospital was laid on 27 June 1908 and the hospital opened on 30 June 1909
Address - Princess Margaret Hospital for Children was located on the corner of Thomas and Hay Streets in Subiaco
Event - The Children's Hospital changed its name to Princess Margaret Hospital for Children

cpfRelation.relationEntry: State Archives Collection of Western Australia (1829 - )
Department of Aboriginal Affairs [predecessors], Records, Department of Aboriginal Affairs (1886 - 2004)
Western Australian Government Records relating to Child Welfare and Protection (1894 - )

descriptiveNote.p: Children with profound intellectual disabilities lived in a special ward at PMH up to the mid-1970s. Princess Margaret Hospital also had a Child Guidance Clinic and assessment centre.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Hospital [Public Hospitals] Records, Western Australia, Department of Health Western Australia (1894 - )

descriptiveNote.p: The Department of Health website gives up to date contact details and instructions on how to apply for records from PMH.
PMH was represented on the Child Abuse Review Panel.
PMH was represented on the Child Sexual Abuse Task Force.
Children who had to come to Perth for treatment at Princess Margaret Hospital for Children , and who had no family to stay with, were often admitted to the Mt Lawley Reception Home.
Children who had to come to Perth for treatment at Princess Margaret Hospital for Children , and who had no family to stay with, were often admitted to the Government Receiving Home.
Children who had to come to Perth for treatment at the children's hospital and who had no family to stay with were often admitted to the Government Receiving Depot.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Beryl Grant interviewed by Christine Choo in the Forgotten Australians and Former Child Migrants oral history project (2011)

descriptiveNote.p: Children may have been transferred between Devonleigh and Princess Margaret Hospital.
The Methodist Children's Home sometimes sent sick children to the Princess Margaret Hospital for Children for treatment.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Lady Lawley Cottage by the Sea (1903 - )

descriptiveNote.p: Children who were in out of home care often went to Lady Lawley Cottage to convalesce after treatment in the children's hospital that was originally the Perth Children's Hospital and later became known as Princess Margaret Hospital. In 1942, children were evacuated from Lady Lawley Cottage to the hospital.
Children were sent to St Joseph's Preventorium from the Princess Margaret Hospital for Children.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: BA533/547: Christmas at Perth Childrens' Hospital, 1922

archref.repository: E.L. Mitchell collection of photographs, State Library of Western Australia
archref.unittitle: BA533/547: Christmas at Perth Childrens' Hospital, 1922
archref.abstract: This is a digitised copy of a photograph and is part of the E. L. Mitchell collection of photographs held at the State Library of Western Australia. The image shows children and nurses in a ward at the Princess Margaret Hospital for Children with Christmas decorations in 1922.
archref.note: This image is for personal use only. To publish or display it, contact the State Library of Western Australia.
